title: Conditionals Type 1 or Type 2 - 3
instructions: Complete the sentences to make type 1 or type 2 conditional sentences.

sentence: They would come with us to the pub if they
(be) cool, but they're just jerks.
explain: Corr: were. There's 'would' in the main clause, so it's type 2 conditional, and we have to use 'were'.

sentence: Do you think they will cooperate if I
(blackmail) them with this sensitive information?
explain: Corr: blackmail. There's 'will' in the main clause, so it's type 1 conditional, and we need present simple.

sentence: What
you do if one of your cousins wanted to live with you?
explain: Corr: would. It's type 2 conditional because there's past tense in the if-clause, so we need 'would'.

sentence: If we
(happen) to find the solution before them, I'd invite everybody for a beer.
explain: Corr: happened. There's 'would' in the main clause, so it's type 2 conditional, and we need past tense in the if-clause.

sentence: I
(help) them only if they pay me. Otherwise, I
(say) no to them.
explain: Corr: will help. There's is present tense in the if-clause, so we need 'will' in the main clause because it's type 1 conditional.
Corr: will help. There's is present tense in the if-clause, so we need 'will' in the main clause because it's type 1 conditional.

sentence: I
(not help) you do your maths homework even if
(be) good at maths, but I'm not.
explain: Corr: wouldn't help. We need type 2 conditional here because the speaker says he or she is not good at maths (...but I'm not.), so it's about an imagined situation.
Corr: were. We need type 2 conditional here because the speaker says he or she is not good at maths (...but I'm not.), so it's about an imagined situation.

sentence: Nobody
(notice) if we go home now. If someone does, we
(bribe) him or her.
explain: Corr: will notice. It's type 1 conditional because there's present tense in the if-clause.
Corr: will bribe. It's type 1 conditional because there's present tense in the if-clause.

sentence: If you
(not do) this task now, then who will do it?
explain: Corr: don't do. It's type 1 conditional and we need present tense in the if-clause because there's 'will' in the main clause.

sentence: Don't park your car here. If you do, your car
(be) towed away.
explain: Corr: will be. It's conditional type 1, and we need 'will' in the main clause because there's present tense in the if-clause.

sentence: If we
(not take) his advice, he would be very angry and he
(never give) us any advice any more.
explain: Corr: didn't take. We need past tense here because there's 'would' in the main clause, so it's type 2 conditional.
